- Stir in garam masala, salt, spinach and coriander leaves. Saute until wilted and cooked through, for 3 to 4 mins. Turn off and stir in the rest of the water.
- Blend using an immersion blender or a stand blender to a smooth or coarse puree, as per your preference. (cool down first, if using a stand blender). Taste test and adjust the green chilies/heat level at this stage.
- Return the palak mixture to the pot and add corn kernels. Bring to a boil and let simmer for 3 to 4 mins. If you are using mature spinach, you may cook for another 3 to 4 mins. Taste test and adjust salt & garam masala. Crush kasuri methi in your hands and sprinkle.
- Turn off and pour the cream. Corn palak is ready to serve at this stage. You may serve it with a squeeze of lemon juice if you don't want to make the tadka.
- Heat five ml ghee in a non-stick pan and place the paneer cubes. Fry until golden on a medium high heat, tossing them around gently. Stir in half to the corn palak and reserve the rest.
- Turn off the heat and add the remaining ghee, cumin seeds and red chilies. When the seeds sizzle, turn on and add the garlic.
- Let fry on a low heat until light golden. Turn off and stir in the hing, red chili powder and the rest of the fried paneer. Mix well and pour this immediately over the corn palak. Garnish with more heavy cream if you want.
- Perform the first step on saute mode and pressure cook for 5 mins after pouring water. I cook basmati rice along with this, placed on a high legged trivet. Gently release the pressure immediately. Follow the rest as mentioned above.
- Nutrition values include paneer, heavy cream, cashews and all other optional ingredients.
- If you any more sides, this can serve 6 people.
- Avoid mature coriander leaves and stalks as it can make your dish taste soapy.
- To use yogurt, whisk it well in a bowl and stir in 2 to forty five g of cooked corn palak. Mix well and add back to the pot. Avoid cooking after adding yogurt. Also omit tomatoes if you are using yogurt.

name: Stuffed Baingan Curry
instructions:
prep_step:
- Wash and slit the small eggplants lengthwise without cutting through the stem.
- Chop onions and tomatoes finely.
- Prepare ginger-garlic paste if not store-bought.

quick_step:
- Prepare and slit the eggplants.
- Make the masala by sautéing onions, tomatoes, and spices.
- Stuff the eggplants with the masala.
- Cook the stuffed eggplants covered until tender.
- Garnish and serve hot.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
- Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw smell disappears.
- Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
- Add turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt; cook the masala until oil separates.
- Stuff the prepared masala mixture into the slits of each eggplant.
- Place the stuffed eggplants in the pan, cover, and cook on low heat until the eggplants are tender.
- Sprinkle garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.

name: Veg Kolhapuri
instructions:
prep_step:
- Wash and chop mixed vegetables into bite-sized pieces.
- Finely chop the onion and puree the tomatoes.
- Grate fresh coconut if using fresh.

quick_step:
- Prepare vegetables and masala ingredients.
- Sauté whole spices and onions.
- Cook tomato puree with spices.
- Add vegetables and cook until tender.
- Garnish and serve hot.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds, cloves, and cinnamon stick; sauté until aromatic.
- Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw smell disappears.
- Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
- Add red chili powder, coriander powder, Kolhapuri masala, and salt; mix well.
- Add chopped mixed vegetables and grated coconut; stir to coat with spices.
- Add water as needed, cover, and cook until vegetables are tender and gravy thickens.
- Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

name: Handi Chicken
instructions:
prep_step:
- Clean and wash the chicken pieces thoroughly.
- Marinate chicken with yogurt, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt; set aside for 15 minutes.
- Chop onions finely and puree tomatoes.
- Prepare ginger and garlic paste.

quick_step:
- Marinate chicken with yogurt and spices.
- Sauté onions, ginger, garlic, and green chilies in oil.
- Cook tomato puree with spices to make the gravy.
- Add chicken and simmer until tender.
- Finish with cream and garnish with coriander.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a handi or deep pan and add cumin seeds until they splutter.
- Add finely chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; cook until raw smell disappears.
- Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates from the masala.
- Add coriander powder, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
- Add marinated chicken and cook covered on medium heat for 25-30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
- Add cream and cook for another 5 minutes to enhance richness.
- Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

name: Paneer Lababdar
instructions:
prep_step:
- Slice or roughly chop onions.
- Slice green chilies and ginger.
- Chop tomatoes and capsicum.
- Cut paneer into cubes.
- Gather and measure all spices and ingredients.

quick_step:
- Prepare and cook onion, garlic, ginger, spices, and tomato base with cashews and mahua seeds; grind into a smooth paste.
- Toss paneer cubes with turmeric, chili powder, and salt; lightly cook to coat.
- Cook onions, green chilies, ginger garlic paste, and masala; add tomatoes and capsicum.
- Add the ground gravy paste and cook to blend flavors.
- Add paneer, fresh cream, butter, fenugreek powder, and garam masala; simmer gently.
- Garnish with coriander and serve with naan or roti.

cook_step:
- Heat 2-forty five ml oil in a bowl, add cumin seeds, garlic cloves, ginger, green chilies, sliced onions, bay leaves, cinnamon stick, and green cardamom; cook on high flame till onions turn translucent.
- Add tomatoes, coriander leaves, salt, Kashmiri red chili powder, turmeric powder, broken Kashmiri red chilies, cashews, and mahua seeds; stir and cook on medium flame till tomatoes soften.
- Add a little hot water, cover and cook on medium-low flame for 10-15 minutes until ingredients are cooked well.
- Remove bay leaves and cinnamon sticks, cool the mixture, then grind it into a fine paste adding water if needed; set aside.
- Heat thirty ml oil in a wok, add paneer cubes, turmeric powder, Kashmiri red chili powder, salt; toss on high flame for 1-1.5 minutes to coat paneer with spices; remove and keep aside.
- In the same wok, heat 3-sixty ml oil, add cumin seeds, green chilies, chopped onions; cook on high flame till onions turn golden brown.
- Add ginger garlic paste, cook for 1-2 minutes to remove raw smell.
- Lower flame, add turmeric powder, Kashmiri red chili powder, coriander powder; add a little water and cook masala for 2-3 minutes.
- Add chopped tomatoes and salt; cook till tomatoes are well cooked.
- Add chopped capsicum, stir and roast for 1 minute.
- Add the prepared ground gravy to the pan, stir well and cook with capsicum for 5-6 minutes; adjust consistency with hot water if needed.
- Add a pinch of sugar and adjust salt; stir well.
- Add the cooked paneer cubes to the gravy.
- Add fresh cream, butter, roasted fenugreek powder, and homemade garam masala; mix gently on low flame.
- Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

name: Ragda Pattice
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak two hundred and fifty g dry white peas in water for 8 hours.
- Soak seventy five g seedless tamarind and two hundred and fifty g seedless dates separately in hot water for 15-20 minutes.
- Chop green chillies and coriander; grate ginger for potato mixture.
- Boil 5-6 medium potatoes, peel and mash them lightly.
- Prepare fresh coriander and mint leaves for green chutney.
- Cool the mashed potato mixture before shaping patties.

quick_step:
- Soak and cook white peas to make ragda.
- Prepare sweet tamarind-date chutney and spicy green chutney.
- Boil and mash potatoes with spices to form patties.
- Fry patties in desi ghee until golden.
- Assemble by topping patties with ragda and chutneys.

cook_step:
- Pressure cook soaked white peas with turmeric, cumin, coriander, fennel powders, and salt for 3 whistles on medium-low flame until soft.
- Grind soaked tamarind and dates into a fine paste, strain to remove fibers, then cook with jaggery, spices, and water on medium-low flame for 25-30 minutes until syrupy consistency is reached to make sweet chutney.
- Grind green coriander, mint, ginger, green chillies, roasted chickpea flour, black salt, cumin powder, mango powder, salt, ice cubes, and water to make green chutney.
- Mash cooked white peas partially to make ragda, cook on medium flame for 5-7 minutes until thickened; add julienned ginger and fresh coriander.
- Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and chopped green chillies, then add boiled potatoes, salt, coriander leaves, and grated ginger; cook on high flame for 2-3 minutes to evaporate moisture.
- Shape cooled potato mixture into medium-sized round patties.
- Heat desi ghee in a pan and shallow fry patties on medium flame until golden brown on both sides.
- Assemble ragda pattice by placing fried patties on a plate, pouring hot ragda over them, and topping with sweet and green chutneys.

name: Chicken Kali Mirch
instructions:
prep_step:
- Wash the chicken well and drain excess water using a strainer.
- Marinate chicken with salt, five g black pepper powder, fifteen ml lemon juice, and fifteen ml curd. Mix well and set aside for 30 minutes or up to 1 day if time permits.
- Roughly chop onions, garlic cloves, ginger, and green chilies.
- Prepare small lemon pieces for later use.

quick_step:
- Marinate chicken with salt, black pepper, lemon juice, and curd.
- Fry onions, garlic, ginger, green chilies, and cashew nuts; grind to a paste.
- Fry chicken with the spice paste and lemon pieces.
- Add curd and roast until oil separates.
- Add water and cook chicken covered for 15 minutes.
- Add final spices and cook until oil separates.
- Serve hot with thick, flavorful gravy.

cook_step:
- Heat thirty ml oil in a pan and fry chopped onions on high flame for 2 minutes.
- Add garlic cloves and ginger, fry until fragrant.
- Add chopped green chilies and cashew nuts, fry the mixture for 3-4 minutes until spices are well cooked and color changes.
- Remove the fried spices leaving the oil in the pan and let them cool.
- Add 2-forty five ml water to the cooled spices and grind to a smooth paste, then add this paste back to the hot oil.
- Increase flame and add marinated chicken, fry on high flame for 5 minutes until the chicken color changes nicely.
- Remove chicken and add lemon pieces and lemon juice to the pan, fry the spices for 3-4 minutes until oil separates.
- Add the fried chicken back to the pan, add salt to taste, and mix well.
- Lower the flame and add remaining curd, mix and roast for 2 minutes until oil separates and gravy thickens.
- Add two hundred and forty ml water, mix, cover, and cook on medium flame for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
- Add garam masala, cumin powder, black pepper powder, and crushed fenugreek leaves, mix well and cook until oil separates and spices are cooked.
- Turn off the heat and serve hot.

name: Mushroom Pepper Fry
instructions:
prep_step:
- Clean and slice the mushrooms.

quick_step:
- Slice mushrooms and slit green chili.
- Heat oil and temper mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chili.
- Add mushrooms and salt, sauté well.
- Add black pepper and cook until mushrooms are done.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
- Once mustard seeds splutter, add curry leaves and green chili.
- Add sliced mushrooms and salt, sauté on medium flame.
- Sprinkle black pepper and cook until mushrooms are tender and slightly crispy.

name: Punjabi Style Rajma Masala
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak kidney beans overnight in enough water.
- Finely chop onions and green chili.

quick_step:
- Soak kidney beans overnight.
- Prepare onion-tomato masala with spices.
- Combine cooked beans with masala and simmer.
- Garnish and serve hot with rice or roti.

cook_step:
- Pressure cook soaked kidney beans with water and salt until soft.
- Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
- Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili, sauté for a minute.
- Add pureed tomatoes and cook until oil separates.
- Add turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder and salt; mix well.
- Add cooked kidney beans along with cooking water, simmer for 15-20 minutes.
- Sprinkle garam masala and cook for another 5 minutes.
- Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

name: Chole with Lachha Paratha
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak chickpeas overnight or for at least 8 hours.
- Drain and rinse soaked chickpeas.
- Mix wheat flour with water and a pinch of salt to make a soft dough for paratha.
- Let the dough rest for 15-20 minutes.

quick_step:
- Soak and pressure cook chickpeas.
- Prepare dough and rest.
- Cook spicy chole gravy.
- Roll and fold dough to create layered Lachha Paratha.
- Cook paratha on griddle with ghee until crisp.
- Serve hot chole with Lachha Paratha.

cook_step:
- Pressure cook chickpeas with salt until soft.
- Heat oil in a pan, add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw smell disappears.
- Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
- Add chole masala, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt; mix well.
- Add cooked chickpeas along with some cooking water and simmer for 15-20 minutes.
- Divide dough into balls, roll each into a circle, apply ghee, fold using the wooden folding method to create layers, roll again into a paratha.
- Cook paratha on a hot griddle with ghee until golden brown and crisp on both sides.

name: Malai Kofta Recipe (Paneer Kofta)
instructions:
prep_step:
- Then immediately pour the tomato onion puree. Be careful and do not burn the spices. You can also do the other way like I did poured the puree first and then added the ground spices.
- If your homemade paneer is too wet with whey, grate it, spread on a tray and leave it uncovered in the refrigerator overnight. Excess moisture will be dried out.
- You can make stuffed kofta with chopped raisins and cashews. In restaurants, fine chopped cashews, raisins and mawa is mixed and stuffed inside the koftas. I prefer to add the nuts and raisins to the kofta mixture instead, for ease of making.
- If you don’t like to saute your onions in oil, simply dry saute for 3 to 4 mins and then continue with the recipe. Though the flavor is different while you saute, the end result is delicious and tastes the same.
- You can substitute ginger garlic paste with chopped/sliced ginger and garlic. Add it when you saute the onions.
- Heat fifteen ml oil in a pan. When the oil turns hot, add cardamoms, cloves & cinnamon.
- Then add onions and saute until they turn transparent or golden.
- Next add tomatoes & cashews. Saute for 2 to 3 mins. Pour half cup water & boil all the ingredients until soft & mushy.
- Turn off the stove and cool completely. Add to a blender jar, retain all the whole spices we used. Don't discard them. Blend this to a smooth puree. Strain the puree (filter) through a strainer to another bowl.
- Heat a pan with oil or butter. Add bay leaf, cinnamon and cardamoms (all spices are optional here). Saute for a minute.
- Add ginger garlic paste and saute on a low heat till the raw smell goes away. This takes about 2 to 3 mins.
- Quickly stir in chili powder, garam masala, coriander powder,salt and sugar. Pour the onion tomato puree. Mix it well.
- Saute for 3 to 4 mins for the raw smell of chili powder to go away.
- Pour one-half to one hundred and eighty ml water to make a gravy. Cook covered until the gravy thickens and traces of oil are seen on top. The raw smell of the ingredients should have gone.
- Add kasuri methi and taste test. If needed add more salt.
- Regulate the flame to low and add cream. Stir and turn off the heat. Set this aside.
- To make malai kofta, boil potatoes just until fork tender and not mushy.
- Crumble them and add to a mixing bowl along with crumbled paneer, ginger paste, corn flour, salt, garam masala and chopped coriander leaves.
- Also add raisins and cashews. Or you can stuff them in the koftas.
- Mix everything well and divide the dough to 8 equal parts. Roll them to balls.
- If you prefer, you can also flatten each ball. Place the cashews and raisins in the center and seal.
- Heat oil in a kadai for deep frying. Check if the oil is hot enough by sliding in a small portion of the malai kofta mixture.
- It has to rise without browning a lot. This is the right temperature.
- Test the dough : Wait for the oil to heat up. Pinch off five g of the kofta mixture and roll to a small ball. Slide it to the hot oil to ensure the mixture is right and does not disintegrate.
- If the ball does not disintegrate or disperse in oil, then go ahead with the next step. If the ball disintegrates, add more corn starch to fix it (refer notes).
- Slide the koftas one by one gently to the hot oil.
- Deep fry on a medium flame until crisp and golden. Remove them to a steel colander or plate.
- Cool the gravy completelt and transfer it to a serving dish.
- Cool the malai koftas slightly. Place them in the gravy and pour fifteen ml of cream. (avoid adding hot koftas to hot gravy)
- Garnish malai kofta with coriander leaves & serve with butter naan or Jeera Rice .
- Mushy potatoes are not suitable to make malai kofta. Too much moisture in your potatoes will disintegrate your koftas. Cook the potatoes just until fork tender.
- If you add the kofta balls to oil that is not hot enough, the balls will disperse in the oil. So ensure the oil is hot enough before you fry the first ball.
- Paneer: You can use store bought paneer or homemade. If using homemade make sure it is completely dry and not soggy. You don’t need to set the paneer after straining and hanging it. I usually put the whole pack of hung paneer uncovered (along with the muslin/ cheese cloth) in the fridge, overnight. By the next day most of the moisture would have gone and it turns out perfect. To substitute paneer, use extra firm tofu. You may need to add more corn starch if your kofta mixture is sticky.
- Potatoes: Make sure you boil the potatoes only until fork tender and not mushy or too soft. Overcooked potatoes retain excess moisture & that’s not good for koftas. If your potatoes are mushy with lots of moisture you may use more corn starch but that can alter the texture of your koftas. So make sure they are boiled whole just until fork tender.
- Corn Starch: Corn starch is the same as white corn flour. It helps the kofta ingredients bind together. Arrow root powder or tapioca flour works well too but make sure you use only little oil to fry them.
- Cashews: Cashews are used in both kofta balls and even in the curry. They add richness, creaminess and milky aroma to the curry. I have used cashews to cut down the amount of cream and that also helps to cut down the calories and makes for a healthier and lighter dish.
- To substitute cashews, you may use cashew meal, almond meal, cashew or almond butter. For a nut-free option, use sunflower seeds, white poppy seeds or magaz seeds (melon seeds).
- Cream: If you want you may skip the cream from the gravy but without cream/malai the dish won’t be malai kofta. But you can still make it equally creamy with the addition of more cashews.

cook_step:
- Then immediately pour the tomato onion puree. Be careful and do not burn the spices. You can also do the other way like I did poured the puree first and then added the ground spices.
- If your homemade paneer is too wet with whey, grate it, spread on a tray and leave it uncovered in the refrigerator overnight. Excess moisture will be dried out.
- You can make stuffed kofta with chopped raisins and cashews. In restaurants, fine chopped cashews, raisins and mawa is mixed and stuffed inside the koftas. I prefer to add the nuts and raisins to the kofta mixture instead, for ease of making.
- If you don’t like to saute your onions in oil, simply dry saute for 3 to 4 mins and then continue with the recipe. Though the flavor is different while you saute, the end result is delicious and tastes the same.
- You can substitute ginger garlic paste with chopped/sliced ginger and garlic. Add it when you saute the onions.
- Heat fifteen ml oil in a pan. When the oil turns hot, add cardamoms, cloves & cinnamon.
- Then add onions and saute until they turn transparent or golden.
- Next add tomatoes & cashews. Saute for 2 to 3 mins. Pour half cup water & boil all the ingredients until soft & mushy.
- Turn off the stove and cool completely. Add to a blender jar, retain all the whole spices we used. Don't discard them. Blend this to a smooth puree. Strain the puree (filter) through a strainer to another bowl.
- Heat a pan with oil or butter. Add bay leaf, cinnamon and cardamoms (all spices are optional here). Saute for a minute.
- Add ginger garlic paste and saute on a low heat till the raw smell goes away. This takes about 2 to 3 mins.
- Quickly stir in chili powder, garam masala, coriander powder,salt and sugar. Pour the onion tomato puree. Mix it well.
- Saute for 3 to 4 mins for the raw smell of chili powder to go away.
- Pour one-half to one hundred and eighty ml water to make a gravy. Cook covered until the gravy thickens and traces of oil are seen on top. The raw smell of the ingredients should have gone.
- Add kasuri methi and taste test. If needed add more salt.
- Regulate the flame to low and add cream. Stir and turn off the heat. Set this aside.
- To make malai kofta, boil potatoes just until fork tender and not mushy.
- Crumble them and add to a mixing bowl along with crumbled paneer, ginger paste, corn flour, salt, garam masala and chopped coriander leaves.
- Also add raisins and cashews. Or you can stuff them in the koftas.
- Mix everything well and divide the dough to 8 equal parts. Roll them to balls.
- If you prefer, you can also flatten each ball. Place the cashews and raisins in the center and seal.
- Heat oil in a kadai for deep frying. Check if the oil is hot enough by sliding in a small portion of the malai kofta mixture.
- It has to rise without browning a lot. This is the right temperature.
- Test the dough : Wait for the oil to heat up. Pinch off five g of the kofta mixture and roll to a small ball. Slide it to the hot oil to ensure the mixture is right and does not disintegrate.
- If the ball does not disintegrate or disperse in oil, then go ahead with the next step. If the ball disintegrates, add more corn starch to fix it (refer notes).
- Slide the koftas one by one gently to the hot oil.
- Deep fry on a medium flame until crisp and golden. Remove them to a steel colander or plate.
- Cool the gravy completelt and transfer it to a serving dish.
- Cool the malai koftas slightly. Place them in the gravy and pour fifteen ml of cream. (avoid adding hot koftas to hot gravy)
- Garnish malai kofta with coriander leaves & serve with butter naan or Jeera Rice .
- Mushy potatoes are not suitable to make malai kofta. Too much moisture in your potatoes will disintegrate your koftas. Cook the potatoes just until fork tender.
- If you add the kofta balls to oil that is not hot enough, the balls will disperse in the oil. So ensure the oil is hot enough before you fry the first ball.
- Paneer: You can use store bought paneer or homemade. If using homemade make sure it is completely dry and not soggy. You don’t need to set the paneer after straining and hanging it. I usually put the whole pack of hung paneer uncovered (along with the muslin/ cheese cloth) in the fridge, overnight. By the next day most of the moisture would have gone and it turns out perfect. To substitute paneer, use extra firm tofu. You may need to add more corn starch if your kofta mixture is sticky.
- Potatoes: Make sure you boil the potatoes only until fork tender and not mushy or too soft. Overcooked potatoes retain excess moisture & that’s not good for koftas. If your potatoes are mushy with lots of moisture you may use more corn starch but that can alter the texture of your koftas. So make sure they are boiled whole just until fork tender.
- Corn Starch: Corn starch is the same as white corn flour. It helps the kofta ingredients bind together. Arrow root powder or tapioca flour works well too but make sure you use only little oil to fry them.
- Cashews: Cashews are used in both kofta balls and even in the curry. They add richness, creaminess and milky aroma to the curry. I have used cashews to cut down the amount of cream and that also helps to cut down the calories and makes for a healthier and lighter dish.
- To substitute cashews, you may use cashew meal, almond meal, cashew or almond butter. For a nut-free option, use sunflower seeds, white poppy seeds or magaz seeds (melon seeds).
- Cream: If you want you may skip the cream from the gravy but without cream/malai the dish won’t be malai kofta. But you can still make it equally creamy with the addition of more cashews.

name: Veg Makhanwala
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop tomatoes and onions roughly for the gravy paste.
- Soak cashews in water for a few minutes.
- Chop mixed vegetables: carrot, cauliflower, and beans.

quick_step:
- Prepare a tomato-onion-cashew-curd gravy paste.
- Sauté green chilies in butter and add the gravy paste to cook.
- Add mixed vegetables in order of cooking time and cook covered.
- Finish with paneer and honey, simmer briefly.
- Serve hot with roti or rice.

cook_step:
- Make a fine paste of tomatoes, onions, curd, soaked cashews, oil, and water.
- Heat butter in a pan, add asafoetida and green chilies, sauté until aromatic.
- Add the prepared gravy paste and cook on low flame for about 10 minutes until rawness disappears and oil separates.
- Add chopped vegetables in sequence starting with those that take longer to cook (carrot, cauliflower, beans), add salt and a little water, cover and cook for 10 minutes.
- Stir occasionally, cook until vegetables are tender and gravy thickens with butter/oil separating on top.
- Add paneer cubes and honey, mix gently and cook for another 5 minutes on low flame.
- Adjust salt and consistency, then turn off the heat.

name: Paneer Angara
instructions:
prep_step:
- Cut tomatoes into large pieces.
- Slice ginger into thick pieces.
- Cut green chillies into 2-3 pieces.
- Chop capsicum into small pieces (optional).
- Grate paneer.
- Prepare wood coila (charcoal) for smoking by heating it with a little oil.

quick_step:
- Roast whole spices with tomatoes and cashews, then grind into a paste.
- Prepare masala with dry spices and fenugreek leaves, add the tomato paste and water.
- Add grated paneer and cook the curry on low flame.
- Smoke the curry using hot coila with asafoetida for a smoky flavor.
- Finish with butter or cream and garnish with coriander before serving.

cook_step:
- Heat fifteen ml oil in a wok and add cumin seeds, cinnamon stick, bay leaves, green cardamoms, cloves, black peppercorns, red chilli, green chillies, and cashew nuts; roast lightly.
- Add chopped tomatoes and cover to cook on low flame until tomatoes are tender (about 10 minutes).
- Let the roasted spices and tomatoes cool, then grind into a fine paste.
- Heat 2-forty five ml oil in a pan, add cumin seeds, turmeric powder, ginger paste, coriander powder, red chilli powder, green chilli powder, and dry fenugreek leaves; roast until oil separates.
- Add chopped capsicum and roast along with the masala.
- Add the prepared tomato-spice paste, two hundred and forty ml water, and salt; mix well and bring to a simmer.
- Add grated paneer, mix gently, cover, and cook on low flame for 5 minutes.
- Place a bowl in the center of the pan, put hot coila in the bowl, add asafoetida and a little oil on the coila, cover the pan to trap smoke for 10 minutes to infuse smoky flavor.
- Remove the coila, add butter or cream, garnish with fresh coriander, and mix gently before serving.

name: Chicken Angara
instructions:
prep_step:
- Roast coriander seeds, cumin seeds, red chillies, black pepper, cloves, cardamom, cinnamon, almonds, and cashews on medium-low flame for 2-3 minutes until aromatic.
- Cool the roasted spices and grind them into a fine powder.
- Cut one thousand g chicken into medium-sized pieces.
- Prepare tomato paste by blending 4 big tomatoes (about four hundred g) and add fifteen g red tomato paste.
- Fry 2 big onions until golden brown and set aside.
- Mix chicken with tomato paste, curd, dry fenugreek leaves, Kashmiri red chilli powder, normal red chilli powder, salt, fried onions, roasted spice powder, and oil.
- Marinate the chicken mixture for 1-2 hours or refrigerate overnight for better flavor.

quick_step:
- Roast and grind whole spices with nuts to make a fine spice powder.
- Marinate chicken with tomato paste, curd, fried onions, fenugreek leaves, chilli powders, salt, and the roasted spice powder.
- Cook marinated chicken on high flame briefly, then simmer on low until fully cooked.
- Finish with hot ghee and oil tempering and garnish with coriander.
- Serve hot with Indian breads.

cook_step:
- Cook the marinated chicken on high flame for 3-4 minutes to avoid burning the spices.
- Reduce the flame to low, cover with a lid, and cook until the chicken is fully cooked, stirring occasionally to prevent spices from sticking.
- Once chicken is cooked and masala is thickened, garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
- Add some ghee and hot oil to a small bowl, heat until smoking, then pour over the cooked chicken for added aroma and richness.
- Serve hot with roti, naan, or paratha.

name: Butter Chicken Recipe (Indian Chicken Makhani)
instructions:
prep_step:
- Also add 28 whole cashews (forty two g, seventy nine and 0.2 g) – (or omit nuts to substitute with one-quarter to one-third heavy cream later at the end)
- Pour half cup water to the blender. Grind to a smooth puree. Alternately, If you do not have a powerful blender, you may soak the cashews in one hundred and twenty ml hot water for 30 mins and then puree them separately in a small coffee grinder like the way I did.
- Marination is the key to get flavorful, tender & succulent pieces of chicken.
- Yogurt in the marinade tenderizes the chicken so do not skip it.
- Makhani recipe never uses onion. However using them helps to balance the tang/sour taste of tomatoes, especially if you are using passata or canned tomatoes.
- The rich taste in the gravy comes from the cashews (or almonds) & cream.
- You can make the gravy ahead and refrigerate. Just grill the marinated chicken when needed and heat up the gravy. Then add the grilled chicken.
- Marinate chicken with lemon juice, chili powder and salt. Cover and rest for 20 minutes. Next add yogurt, kasuri methi, oil, turmeric, ginger garlic paste, coriander powder, cumin powder and garam masala powder.
- Marinate and rest for a minimum of 30 minutes, or overnight for best results. Cover and refrigerate.
- Optional – If using onion, sauté in fifteen ml oil until lightly golden, for 7 minutes. Cool down.
- To a blender, add tomatoes, sautéed onions, cashews and water. Blend to a smooth puree. If you want you can also blend the cashews separately with water to a smooth cream.
- Remove the chicken from the refrigerator, to bring it close to room temperature.
- Melt butter in a pan & add all the whole spices – cinnamon, cloves and cardamoms.
- When they begin to sizzle, stir in the ginger garlic paste & green chilies. Fry on a low heat, for a minute or 2, till it turns fragrant but not burnt.
- Turn off the heat and stir in red chili powder, garam masala, cumin and coriander powder.
- Stir in the tomato cashew puree. If it is not smooth, strain it to the pan.
- Mix well and cover partially. Bring it to a boil on a medium high heat, reduce the heat to low or medium. Cook until the puree turns thick, keep stirring occasionally.
- Pour hot water and simmer for 10 mins, until the sauce thickens & traces of fats are visible on top of the sauce. Remove the whole spices and discard at this stage.
- Spread one tbsp. butter or ghee in a griddle/pan and heat it well. Place the marinated chicken pieces, spacing them a little apart.
- Fry on a medium heat for 2 mins and turn them. Don’t burn and do not overcook. Cook till the chicken is just cooked and all the marinade dries up. It is not necessary to fully cook the chicken at this stage.
- This way roast the chicken pieces in 2 to 3 batches, depending on the size of your skillet.
- Add chicken to the butter chicken gravy. Pour more hot water (about one hundred and twenty g, not in the recipe) if the sauce is too thick. Cover and simmer for about 5 to 7 minutes till it becomes tender.
- Stir in salt, sugar and kasuri methi. Taste test and optionally add more garam masala & another tablespoon butter for additional flavour (both are optional).
- Turn off and stir in the heavy cream. Garnish Butter Chicken with chopped coriander leaves and some cream. Serve with Turmeric rice , steamed Basmati Rice , Butter naan or Cumin Rice .
- Read my pro tips and Ingredients section in the post.
- Soak cashews in hot boiling water for 15 to 30 mins, if you don’t have a powerful blender.
- Use good quality ripe sweet tomatoes. Avoid using sour/tangy tomatoes.
- Using onions is optional and you may use them to cut down the sour taste of the tomatoes.
- The quantity & type of tomatoes and ground spices determine the color of your butter chicken gravy.
- Butter chicken is a mild curry, using a lot of spices alters the flavor and taste of the sauce.
- If using almonds, soak them in hot water for a few hours and remove the skin. Grind them with half cup water. You can also use sixty g blanched almond flour, grind it with half cup water until really smooth.
- You can also use 1 -14 oz whole peeled tomatoes to sub fresh tomatoes

cook_step:
- Also add 28 whole cashews (forty two g, seventy nine and 0.2 g) – (or omit nuts to substitute with one-quarter to one-third heavy cream later at the end)
- Pour half cup water to the blender. Grind to a smooth puree. Alternately, If you do not have a powerful blender, you may soak the cashews in one hundred and twenty ml hot water for 30 mins and then puree them separately in a small coffee grinder like the way I did.
- Marination is the key to get flavorful, tender & succulent pieces of chicken.
- Yogurt in the marinade tenderizes the chicken so do not skip it.

- The rich taste in the gravy comes from the cashews (or almonds) & cream.
