- Pairing it with curries like mirchi ka salan and bagara baingan also tastes awesome. Even a simple plain yogurt tastes nice with it.
- Place any leftovers in any sealed box or container and refrigerate for 1 to 2 days. Reheat by warming in the oven at 90 degrees Celsius (190 degrees Fahrenheit) or by steaming in the Instant pot for 5 minutes.

name: Paneer Sandwich Toasted
instructions:
prep_step:
- Crumble the paneer and mix with finely chopped green chili, coriander leaves, salt, and black pepper.
- Sprinkle flour over the bread slices to help with binding and crispiness.

quick_step:
- Prepare paneer filling by mixing crumbled paneer with spices and herbs.
- Sprinkle flour on bread slices.
- Toast sandwich in butter until crispy and golden.

cook_step:
- Spread the paneer mixture evenly on one slice of bread and cover with another slice.
- Heat a pan and add butter.
- Place the sandwich on the pan and press gently with a spatula.
- Toast each side until golden brown and crispy.

name: Bombay Masala Toast Sandwich
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil and peel the potatoes, then mash them slightly.
- Chop garlic, ginger, green chilies, coriander leaves, cucumber, capsicum, beetroot, and tomatoes into thin slices.
- Prepare the special green chutney by grinding coriander, garlic, green chilies, desiccated coconut, salt, lemon juice, and water to a smooth but thick consistency.
- Roast cumin seeds, fennel seeds, and black pepper, then grind with red chili powder, chaat masala, and salt to make the shortcut sandwich masala.

quick_step:
- Prepare potato masala by frying spices and mixing with boiled potatoes.
- Make green chutney by grinding coriander, garlic, chilies, coconut, lemon juice, and salt.
- Butter bread slices and spread chutney and cheese.
- Assemble sandwich with potato masala, vegetables, and sprinkle sandwich masala.
- Toast sandwich on low-medium heat until golden and crispy.
- Serve hot with chutneys.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a wok and add mustard seeds, curry leaves, garlic, ginger, and green chilies; fry on medium flame until aromatic.
- Add turmeric powder and coriander leaves, fry briefly, then add the boiled potatoes and salt; mix well and cook for 2-3 minutes to make the potato masala. Let it cool.
- Spread butter on one side of each bread slice to prevent sogginess and to help crisp the bread when toasted.
- Spread the green chutney evenly over the buttered side of the bread.
- Grate or slice cheese and spread on the chutney layer.
- Shape the potato masala into medium-sized flat tikkas and place them on the cheese layer, keeping them centered.
- Add cucumber slices on top of the potato tikka, sprinkle the shortcut sandwich masala and salt, then layer tomato slices, capsicum, and beetroot slices.
- Cover with another slice of bread, butter the top lightly, and toast on a gas toaster or pan on low to medium flame until golden brown and crispy on both sides, about 1-1.5 minutes per side.
- Remove and serve hot with additional green chutney and red chutney.

name: Potato Smiley Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil and peel the potatoes, then mash them until smooth.
- Add cornflour, salt, and black pepper to the mashed potatoes and mix well to form a dough.

quick_step:
- Boil and mash potatoes.
- Mix in cornflour and seasonings to form dough.
- Shape into smiley faces.
- Deep fry until golden and crisp.
- Serve hot as a snack.

cook_step:
- Shape the dough into small round discs and create smiley face impressions on each.
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan and fry the shaped potato smileys until golden and crispy.
- Remove and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.

name: Aloo Tikki Chaat
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil the potatoes until soft and cool them.
- Grate the boiled potatoes finely.
- Chop green chilies and grate ginger.
- Chop coriander leaves finely.

quick_step:
- Boil and grate potatoes.
- Mix potatoes with spices, herbs, and flours to bind.
- Shape into tikkis and coat with flour.
- Shallow fry until crispy and golden.

cook_step:
- In a bowl, mix grated potatoes with green chilies, ginger, salt, black salt, roasted cumin powder, chaat masala, garam masala, Kashmiri red chili powder, coriander leaves, rice flour, and corn flour.
- Add a little oil and bind the mixture well to form a dough-like consistency.
- Shape the mixture into round flat tikkis (patties).
- Coat each tikki lightly with rice flour or corn flour.
- Heat oil in a pan and shallow fry the tikkis on medium heat until they turn golden brown and crispy on both sides.
- Remove and drain excess oil.

name: Dahi Aloo Tikki
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil and mash the potatoes until smooth.
- Mix mashed potatoes with spices and salt.
- Shape the mixture into small round tikkis (patties).
- Lightly coat each tikki with flour to help crispiness.

quick_step:
- Boil and mash potatoes.
- Mix with spices and form patties.
- Coat patties with flour and fry until crispy.
- Top fried tikkis with yogurt and chutneys.
- Serve immediately as a snack.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and shallow fry the tikkis until golden and crispy on both sides.
- Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.
- Arrange fried tikkis on a serving plate.
- Top with chilled yogurt and drizzle with tamarind and mint chutneys.
- Garnish with additional spices or sev if desired.

name: Soya Chaap Tikka
instructions:
prep_step:
- Cut the soya chaap into pieces and boil them.
- Fry the boiled chaap pieces lightly.
- Prepare the marination by mixing runny curd with desired spices.
- Add maida to the chaap pieces for binding.
- Add the chaap and chopped vegetables into the marination and mix well.
- Let the chaap soak in the marination for at least 15 minutes.

quick_step:
- Boil and fry soya chaap pieces.
- Prepare a spiced curd marination and add maida for binding.
- Marinate chaap and vegetables for 15 minutes.
- Skewer the marinated ingredients with onions.
- Grill or pan-cook until charred and cooked through.
- Serve hot and enjoy.

cook_step:
- Thread the marinated chaap and vegetables onto skewers, alternating with chopped onions to hold them.
- Grill the skewers on a pan or tandoor until cooked and slightly charred, turning occasionally.
- If skewers are not available, cook the marinated mixture directly in a pan on medium heat until done.

name: Crispy Corn Pepper Fry
instructions:
prep_step:
- Wash and drain the corn kernels thoroughly.
- In a mixing bowl, combine corn kernels with cornflour, maida, black pepper powder, red chili powder, ginger garlic paste, and salt.
- Mix well to coat the corn evenly with the spices and flours.

quick_step:
- Mix corn kernels with flours and spices.
- Heat oil for deep frying.
- Fry the coated corn until crispy and golden.
- Drain excess oil and serve hot.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
- Once the oil is hot, carefully drop the coated corn kernels into the oil in batches.
- Fry the corn until they turn golden brown and crispy.
- Remove the fried corn using a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
- Serve hot as a crispy and spicy snack.

name: Cheesy Vegetable Nachos
instructions:
prep_step:
- Grate two hundred g of mozzarella cheese and keep aside.
- Chop green and red capsicum into equal-sized pieces.
- Slice black and green olives.
- Mix chopped capsicum, cooked corn kernels, sliced olives, and two hundred and forty g grated mozzarella cheese in a bowl.
- Add Italian seasoning, chili flakes, black pepper, and salt to the vegetable mixture.
- Add tomato ketchup and mix well to coat the vegetables and cheese evenly without making it too saucy.

quick_step:
- Grate cheese and chop vegetables.
- Mix vegetables with cheese, seasoning, and ketchup.
- Layer nacho chips on a plate and spread the topping evenly.
- Sprinkle extra cheese on top.
- Melt cheese in a pan or oven for 10-15 minutes.
- Serve hot and enjoy cheesy vegetable nachos.

cook_step:
- Arrange nacho chips evenly on a heatproof plate.
- Spread the prepared vegetable and cheese topping evenly over the nacho chips.
- Sprinkle additional grated mozzarella cheese on top for extra cheesiness.
- Place the plate in a pan or oven to melt the cheese, covering the pan if using stove method.
- Allow the cheese to melt completely for about 10-15 minutes until gooey and bubbly.
- Remove from heat and serve immediately.

name: Masala Peanuts
instructions:
prep_step:
- Clean and rinse the raw peanuts and drain well.
- In a mixing bowl, combine besan, red chili powder, salt, and optional spices.
- Add water little by little to make a thick batter that can coat the peanuts well.
- Add the peanuts to the batter and mix thoroughly so each peanut is coated evenly.

quick_step:
- Prepare a spicy chickpea flour batter.
- Coat raw peanuts thoroughly with the batter.
- Deep fry the coated peanuts until crispy and golden.
- Drain and cool before serving as a crunchy snack.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium heat.
- Once the oil is hot, add the batter-coated peanuts in small batches.
- Fry the peanuts until they turn golden brown and crispy, stirring occasionally.
- Remove the fried peanuts with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
- Allow them to cool completely before serving.

name: Instant Poha Chivda
instructions:
prep_step:
- Rinse poha lightly and drain excess water.
- Gather and measure all ingredients.

quick_step:
- Rinse and drain poha.
- Heat oil and fry mustard seeds and peanuts.
- Add red chilies and curry leaves.
- Add poha and salt, roast until crisp.
- Cool and serve as a snack.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds; let them splutter.
- Add peanuts and fry until golden and crunchy.
- Add red chilies and curry leaves; sauté for a few seconds.
- Add the poha and salt; mix well and roast on low flame until crisp.
- Turn off heat and let the chivda cool before storing.

name: Crispy Murukku
instructions:
prep_step:
- Combine rice flour, all-purpose flour, salt, and cumin seeds in a mixing bowl.
- Gradually add water and knead to form a smooth, pliable dough.

quick_step:
- Mix flours with salt and cumin seeds.
- Knead into a smooth dough using water.
- Press dough into shapes using murukku maker.
- Deep fry until golden and crispy.
- Drain and serve.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat.
- Fill a murukku press with the dough and press out spiral shapes directly into the hot oil.
- Fry until golden brown and crispy, turning occasionally.
- Remove and drain on paper towels.

name: Thattai Crisps
instructions:
prep_step:
- Roast urad dal until golden brown and grind into a fine powder.
- Roast rice flour on medium flame without changing its color to remove moisture.
- Finely chop garlic and curry leaves; fry groundnut leaves until crisp.
- Mix roasted rice flour and urad dal flour with salt, chili powder, asafoetida, chopped garlic, curry leaves, and fried groundnut leaves.
- Add hot oil to the mixture and mix well before adding water.
- Gradually add water and knead into a firm, sandy dough.

quick_step:
- Roast and grind urad dal; roast rice flour to remove moisture.
- Mix flours with spices, chopped garlic, curry leaves, and fried groundnut leaves.
- Add hot oil and knead with water into a firm dough.
- Shape dough into small discs and deep fry on medium heat until crispy and golden.
- Drain and cool before serving as a crunchy evening snack.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan on medium flame for deep frying.
- Take small portions of dough and shape into small discs (thattai), not too thin or thick.
- Carefully slide the discs into hot oil and fry on medium heat until golden brown and crispy, about 6-8 minutes.
- Flip the thattais occasionally to ensure even frying.
- Remove the fried thattais and drain excess oil on paper towels.
- Allow to cool completely before storing in an airtight container.

name: Masala Boiled Egg Chaat
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil the eggs, peel them, and cut into halves or quarters.
- Chop fresh coriander leaves finely.

quick_step:
- Boil and peel eggs.
- Mix spices and lemon juice.
- Add chutneys and garnish with coriander.
- Serve immediately as a spicy snack.

cook_step:
- Mix red chili powder, chaat masala, salt, and lemon juice in a bowl.
- Add the boiled eggs to the spice mix and gently toss to coat evenly.
- Add green chutney and tamarind chutney and mix well.
- Garnish with chopped coriander leaves before serving.

name: Ribbon Pakoda
instructions:
prep_step:
- Mix rice flour, chickpea flour, red chili powder, asafoetida, cumin seeds, and salt in a bowl.
- Add melted butter and mix well.
- Gradually add water and knead into a smooth, firm dough.

quick_step:
- Prepare dough by mixing flours, spices, butter, and water.
- Heat oil for deep frying.
- Press dough into hot oil using ribbon pakoda mold.
- Fry until golden and crispy.
- Drain and cool before serving.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium heat.
- Fill the ribbon pakoda press with dough and press the dough directly into the hot oil in ribbon shapes.
- Fry until the pakodas turn golden brown and crispy.
- Remove and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.

name: Medu Vada Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak urad dal in water for 4-5 hours or overnight.
- Drain the water and grind the dal to a smooth batter with little water.
- Add chopped green chili, grated ginger, curry leaves, crushed black pepper, and salt to the batter.
- Mix well and allow the batter to ferment for 6-8 hours if possible.

quick_step:
- Soak and grind urad dal to a smooth batter.
- Mix in spices and ferment the batter.
- Shape the batter into vadas.
- Deep fry until golden and crispy.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium heat.
- Wet your hands and shape the batter into doughnut-shaped vadas.
- Carefully slide the shaped vadas into hot oil.
- Fry until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
- Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.

name: Leftover Fried Idli Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop onions, tomatoes, red chilli, and green chilli.
- Cut leftover idlis into bite-sized pieces.

quick_step:
- Chop onions, tomatoes, and chillies.
- Cut leftover idlis into pieces.
- Fry cumin and asafoetida in hot oil.
- Sauté onions and tomatoes with spices.
- Add idli pieces and fry briefly.
- Serve hot.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds and asafoetida; fry until fragrant.
- Add chopped onions and tomatoes, season with salt, and sauté for 5 minutes until soft.
- Add black pepper, red chilli, and green chilli; mix well.
- Add the idli pieces and stir-fry for 2 minutes until they are heated through and slightly crispy.
- Serve hot as a snack.

name: Schezwan Idli Fry
instructions:
prep_step:
- Slice the idlis into bite-sized pieces.
- Slice onions and capsicum, chop green chili, mince garlic and ginger.

quick_step:
- Slice idlis and vegetables.
- Sauté aromatics and vegetables in oil.
- Add idlis and stir-fry until crispy.
- Mix in schezwan and soy sauce.
- Cook briefly and serve hot.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic, ginger, and green chili until fragrant.
- Add sliced onions and capsicum, stir-fry until slightly soft.
- Add the idli pieces and stir-fry on medium heat until they turn slightly crispy.
- Add schezwan sauce, soy sauce, and salt; mix well to coat the idlis evenly.
- Cook for another 2-3 minutes, stirring continuously to avoid sticking.

name: Mini Rava Uttapam Bites
instructions:
prep_step:
- Finely chop onion, tomato, green chilies, and coriander leaves.
- In a bowl, mix yogurt, water, and salt.
- Add rava (semolina) to the yogurt mixture and stir well to form a batter of medium consistency.
- Add baking soda to the batter and mix gently.
- Let the batter rest for a few minutes until it thickens slightly.

quick_step:
- Prepare batter by mixing yogurt, water, rava, salt, and baking soda.
- Chop vegetables finely.
- Pour batter on pan and top with vegetables.
- Cook both sides until golden and crisp.
- Serve hot with chutney and sambar.

cook_step:
- Heat a pan and add a little oil.
- Pour a small ladle of batter onto the pan to form mini uttapam bites.
- Sprinkle finely chopped onion, tomato, green chilies, and coriander on top of the batter.
- Cook on medium heat until the edges turn golden and the bottom is cooked.
- Flip the uttapam and cook the other side until done and slightly crisp.
- Remove from pan and serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Instant Rava Dhokla
instructions:
prep_step:
- Grind or finely chop green chili.
- Mix suji, curd, green chili, and ginger paste in a bowl.
- Add water gradually to make a thick batter similar to idly batter consistency.
- Let the batter rest for 10 minutes to soften.
- Add salt and powdered sugar (optional) to the batter and mix well.
- Add five ml water to eno fruit salt and mix it into the batter just before steaming.

quick_step:
- Mix suji, curd, ginger paste, green chili and water to make a thick batter.
- Rest the batter for 10 minutes, then add salt, sugar, and eno fruit salt.
- Steam the batter in a greased container for 20 minutes until fluffy.
- Prepare tadka with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.
- Pour tadka over the steamed dhokla and serve warm.

cook_step:
- Heat water in a steamer or large vessel and bring it to a boil.
- Grease the steaming container with oil and pour the batter into it.
- Place the container in the steamer, cover with a lid, and steam on medium heat for 20 minutes.
- Check doneness by inserting a knife; it should come out clean.
- Remove the dhokla and let it cool slightly.
- Prepare tadka by heating oil in a pan, adding mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chili strips.
- Pour the tadka evenly over the dhokla before serving.

name: Khaman Dhokla
instructions:
prep_step:
- Measure two hundred and forty g besan and two hundred and forty ml curd using the same container for accuracy.
- Add salt and 2 pinches of turmeric powder to the besan.
- Mix besan and curd together with water to make a smooth batter without lumps; whisk for at least 5 minutes to get a moist and spongy texture.
- Let the batter rest covered for 10-15 minutes to ferment slightly.
- Heat water in a steamer or wok for steaming the dhokla.
- Grease a 6-inch cake tin or any steaming plate with oil.

quick_step:
- Prepare a smooth batter of besan, curd, turmeric, salt, and water; whisk well and rest.
- Add baking powder and eno fruit salt just before steaming.
- Steam the batter in a greased tin for 15 minutes until cooked.
- Prepare a tempering of mustard seeds, green chili, curry leaves, sugar, and lemon juice.
- Pour tempering over cut dhokla pieces and garnish with coriander and coconut.

cook_step:
- Just before steaming, add one and one-quarter g baking powder and 1 sachet eno fruit salt to the batter and mix quickly.
- Pour the batter immediately into the greased steaming tin.
- Place the tin in the steamer with hot water and cover immediately.
- Steam on high flame for 15 minutes without opening the lid.
- Check doneness with a toothpick or knife; it should come out clean.
- Turn off the flame and keep the dhokla covered for another 10-15 minutes to cool.
- Prepare tempering by heating oil, adding mustard seeds, asafoetida, chopped green chili, and curry leaves until aromatic.
- Add water, sugar, salt, and lemon juice to the tempering and cook until sugar dissolves.
- Cut the dhokla into pieces and pour the tempering over it to soak.
- Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and optionally grated coconut before serving.

name: Handvo Slices
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak rice in water for 3-4 hours and drain.
- Soak moong dal and urad dal separately in water for 4 hours and drain.
- Grind soaked rice and dals together with about 1.one thousand two hundred ml water to make a thick batter.
- Grate bottle gourd and carrot; finely chop green chillies and coriander; grate ginger.
- Mix grated vegetables, ginger paste, green chillies, red chili powder, turmeric powder, salt, curd (or lemon juice), and coriander into the batter to form a thick mixture.
- Prepare tempering by heating oil and adding mustard seeds, cumin seeds, sesame seeds, and curry leaves; set aside.

quick_step:
- Soak rice and dals, then grind into a thick batter.
- Mix grated vegetables, spices, curd, and tempering into the batter.
- Add eno fruit salt to make the batter fluffy.
- Cook half the batter in a pan on low flame, flipping once.
- Bake the other half in a preheated oven at 200°C until golden brown.
- Cool slightly, slice, and serve with chutney.

cook_step:
- Divide the batter into two parts.
- Add thirty g of tempering and 1.twenty five g of eno fruit salt (or baking soda) to one part; mix well.
- Heat a non-stick pan, spread 2-fifteen g of tempering on it, pour the batter, cover and cook on low-medium flame for 10-12 minutes until cooked and browned on bottom.
- Flip the cooked handvo carefully using a plate, cook the other side for another 10 minutes on low-medium flame until fully cooked and spongy.
- For the second part of the batter, mix ten g tempering and five g eno fruit salt; pour into a greased oven-safe container, sprinkle sesame seeds on top.
- Preheat oven to 200°C and bake the batter for 30 minutes, checking at 20 minutes and continuing until golden brown and fully cooked.
- Remove both pan-cooked and oven-baked handvo from heat, let cool slightly, then cut into slices and serve.

name: Kothimbir Vadi
instructions:
prep_step:
- Roast peanuts with sesame seeds in oil until crispy and set aside.
- Wash and finely chop fresh coriander leaves, ensuring they are dry.
- Grate ginger and finely chop green chilies.
- Measure and prepare all dry and wet ingredients.

quick_step:
- Prepare batter by mixing besan, rice flour, water, curd, and spices.
- Cook batter on stove until thickened, then mix in chopped coriander and roasted peanuts.
- Spread mixture in a tray and let it set.
- Cut into pieces and deep fry until golden and crispy.
- Serve hot with chutney or sauce.

cook_step:
- In a wok, heat fifteen ml oil and add cumin seeds; reduce flame to avoid burning.
- Add thirty ml sesame oil, a pinch of asafoetida, and a little salt.
- Mix besan, rice flour, water, curd, ginger, green chili, coriander powder, turmeric, red chili, salt, and sugar to form a smooth batter without lumps.
- Add roasted peanuts and stir well.
- Pour the batter into the wok on low flame and cook on medium flame, stirring continuously to avoid lumps, until the batter thickens and forms a thick dough-like consistency.
- Add chopped coriander leaves and mix thoroughly.
- Transfer the mixture to an oiled tray or plate and spread evenly.
- Let it cool and set for 30 minutes at room temperature or in the fridge.
- Cut the set mixture into barfi-like pieces.
- Heat oil in a pan on high flame and fry the pieces in batches until golden brown and crispy on all sides, about 3-4 minutes per side.
- Drain excess oil and serve hot with chutney or sauce.

name: Sabudana Vada
instructions:
prep_step:
- Rinse sabudana thoroughly and soak in water for 2-3 hours until soft.
- Dry roast peanuts and grind coarsely.
- Boil and mash potatoes.
- Mix soaked sabudana, mashed potatoes, ground peanuts, chopped green chili, cumin seeds, coriander leaves, and salt in a bowl.
- Shape the mixture into small round patties.

quick_step:
- Soak sabudana until soft.
- Mix with mashed potatoes, peanuts, and spices.
- Shape into patties.
- Deep fry until golden and crispy.
- Serve hot as a snack.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium heat.
- Fry the patties in hot oil until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
- Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.

name: Sprouts Chaat Bowl
instructions:
prep_step:
- Wash and soak the mixed sprouts overnight or use pre-sprouted legumes.
- Finely chop the tomato, onion, green chili, and coriander leaves.

quick_step:
- Soak or use pre-sprouted mixed legumes.
- Chop fresh vegetables and herbs.
- Mix sprouts with chopped veggies and spices.
- Add lemon juice and toss well.
- Serve immediately as a healthy snack.

cook_step:
- No cooking required; this is a raw salad preparation.

name: Sabudana Tikki
instructions:
prep_step:
- Rinse sabudana well and soak in water for 6-8 hours or overnight until soft.
- Drain excess water from soaked sabudana.
- Boil and mash the potato.
- Roast peanuts and crush them coarsely.
- Chop green chilies and coriander leaves.
- Mix soaked sabudana, mashed potato, crushed peanuts, green chilies, cumin seeds, salt, and coriander leaves into a dough.

quick_step:
- Soak sabudana overnight until soft.
- Mix soaked sabudana with mashed potato, peanuts, and spices.
- Shape into patties.
- Shallow fry until crispy and golden.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan for shallow frying.
- Shape the mixture into small round tikkis (patties).
- Shallow fry the tikkis on medium heat until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
- Remove and drain on paper towels.

name: Moong Dal Chilla Roll
instructions:
prep_step:
- Soak moong dal for 2-3 hours and drain.
- Grind soaked moong dal with cumin seeds, salt, turmeric, black pepper powder, cumin powder, onion, garlic, and pepper to form a smooth batter.
- Chop onions finely and prepare paneer slices.
- Prepare green chutney.

quick_step:
- Soak and grind moong dal with spices and onion to make batter.
- Spread batter on pan to make thin pancakes (chillas).
- Cook chillas on both sides until golden.
- Spread chutney and add paneer slices on chilla.
- Roll chilla and serve with chutneys.

cook_step:
- Heat a non-stick pan and pour a ladle of batter, spreading it thinly into a round chilla.
- Cook on medium heat until edges start to lift and the bottom is golden brown.
- Flip and cook the other side until done.
- Remove from pan, spread green chutney, place paneer slices, and roll the chilla.
- Serve immediately with red and green chutney.

name: Besan Chilla Stuffed Roll
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop onion, tomato, green chili, and three types of green beans into big pieces.

quick_step:
- Chop vegetables.
- Mix besan with vegetables and spices to make batter.
- Cook batter on a buttered pan to make chilla.
- Serve hot as a snack or roll with stuffing.

cook_step:
- In a bowl, mix besan, chopped vegetables, salt, turmeric, mango powder, and water to form a batter of medium consistency.
- Heat a pan and add a little butter.
- Pour the besan mixture onto the pan and spread it evenly to form a chilla.
- Cook on medium heat until the chilla is cooked through and slightly crispy on the edges.

name: Paneer Puff
instructions:
prep_step:
- Crumble the paneer and set aside.
- Finely chop the onion, green chili, and coriander leaves.
- Prepare puff pastry sheets by thawing if frozen and cutting into desired sizes.

quick_step:
- Prepare and crumble paneer filling with spices and onions.
- Cut and prepare puff pastry sheets.
- Fill pastry with paneer mixture and seal edges.
- Brush with milk or egg wash.
- Bake until golden and flaky.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan on medium heat and add cumin seeds.
- Add chopped onions and green chili, sauté until translucent.
- Add crumbled paneer, garam masala, salt, and mix well.
- Cook the mixture for 5-7 minutes until flavors combine, then add coriander leaves and remove from heat.
- Place a spoonful of the paneer filling onto each puff pastry piece, fold and seal edges using water or milk.
- Brush the puff pastries with milk or egg wash and bake in a preheated oven at 180°C (350°F) for 20-25 minutes or until golden and puffed.

name: Veg Puff
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop onions, carrots, and green chili finely.
- Boil and dice the potato.
- Prepare the dough by mixing all-purpose flour with butter, oil, salt, and water; knead until smooth and set aside.
- Gather all spices and vegetables for the filling.

quick_step:
- Prepare dough and set aside.
- Cook vegetable filling with spices.
- Roll dough, fill with vegetable mixture, and seal.
- Bake or fry until golden and crispy.

cook_step:
- Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until translucent.
- Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili; cook for a minute.
- Add chopped carrots, peas, and boiled potatoes; stir well.
- Add coriander powder, garam masala, red chili powder, and salt; cook until vegetables are tender and mixture is dry.
- Roll out the dough and cut into small circles or squares.
- Place a spoonful of vegetable filling on each piece, fold and seal the edges.
- Bake or deep fry the puffs until golden brown and flaky.

name: Bakery Style Egg Puff
instructions:
prep_step:
- Mix maida flour with hot water and salt to form a dough.
- Knead the dough well and let it rest for about half an hour.
- Chop green chillies and onions finely.
- Prepare the egg masala by cooking chopped onions, green chillies, and ginger garlic paste with turmeric, coriander powder, and garam masala for 2 minutes, then set aside.

quick_step:
- Prepare dough by mixing maida, hot water, and salt.
- Cook spicy egg masala with onions and spices.
- Roll and fold dough with butter to create layers.
- Fill dough with egg masala and fold into square puffs.
- Brush with egg and bake until soft and flaky.

cook_step:
- Roll out the dough and spread it evenly.
- Fold the dough into a square shape with butter layered inside to create flakiness.
- Place half of the prepared egg masala on top of the folded dough and fold again into a square shape.
- Spread beaten egg on top of the puff.
- Bake or cook the puff for about 40 minutes until soft and cooked through.

name: Cheesy Chicken Puffs
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop chicken into small pieces or mince it.
- Finely chop onions and mince garlic.
- Grate the cheese.
- Thaw puff pastry sheets if frozen.

quick_step:
- Prepare chicken filling by cooking chicken with spices and cheese.
- Cut and prepare puff pastry squares.
- Fill pastry with chicken mixture and seal.
- Brush with egg wash and bake until golden.

cook_step:
- Heat butter in a pan and sauté onions and garlic until translucent.
- Add chicken pieces and cook until tender.
- Add red chili powder, black pepper, salt, and mixed herbs; cook for a few more minutes.
- Remove from heat and mix in grated cheese.
- Cut puff pastry into squares, place a spoonful of chicken mixture in the center.
- Fold the pastry over to form a puff and seal the edges.
- Brush with beaten egg for a golden finish.
- Bake in a preheated oven at 180°C (350°F) for 20-25 minutes or until golden and puffed.

name: Chicken Popcorn Bites
instructions:
prep_step:
- Grind Kashmiri red chilli, spicy red chilli, onion powder, garlic powder, black pepper powder, amchur powder, oregano, salt, and sugar to make peri peri masala.
- Cut chicken breast into bite-size pieces.
- Marinate chicken with salt, peri peri masala, vinegar, and ginger-garlic paste. Mix well and set aside.
- In a bowl, mix maida with salt.
- Coat chicken pieces with the dry flour mixture, remove excess flour, then dip into ice cold water for a few seconds.
- Coat the dipped chicken pieces again with the dry flour mixture to create a crispy texture.

quick_step:
- Prepare peri peri masala by grinding spices.
- Marinate chicken pieces with masala, vinegar, and ginger-garlic paste.
- Double coat chicken pieces with flour and dip in ice cold water.
- Deep fry chicken at 175°C until golden and crisp.
- Sprinkle with peri peri masala and toss before serving.

cook_step:
- Heat oil to 175 degrees Celsius on high flame.
- Deep fry the coated chicken pieces quickly until they turn crisp and golden brown.
- Drain excess oil and immediately sprinkle generously with peri peri masala.
- Toss well to coat the chicken popcorn bites evenly.

name: Zero Oil Fish Finger Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Cut the fish fillet into finger-sized strips.
- Marinate the fish strips with lemon juice, salt, black pepper, and mixed herbs for 10 minutes.
- Coat each fish strip evenly with cornflour.
- Dip the cornflour-coated fish strips into water or a light batter if desired.
- Roll the strips in breadcrumbs to coat thoroughly.

quick_step:
- Cut and marinate fish strips.
- Coat with cornflour and breadcrumbs.
- Bake or air fry until crispy.

cook_step:
- Preheat an air fryer or oven to 180°C (350°F).
- Place the coated fish fingers on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.
- Cook for 12-15 minutes until the fish fingers are crispy and cooked through, flipping halfway if needed.

name: Andaa Bhurji Pav
instructions:
prep_step:
- Finely chop onion, tomato, and capsicum (shimla mirch).
- Finely chop green chili.
- Crack eggs into a bowl, season with salt and pepper, and whisk until smooth.

quick_step:
- Chop vegetables and whisk eggs with seasoning.
- Sauté spices and onions in butter and ghee.
- Add tomatoes, capsicum, and cook until soft.
- Pour in eggs and cook gently on low heat.
- Finish with cream, butter, and coriander.
- Toast pav bread with butter and serve with bhurji.
- Optionally, grate parmesan cheese on top.

cook_step:
- Heat butter and ghee in a pan until melted.
- Add curry powder, cumin seeds, ginger-garlic paste, and chopped onion; sauté until softened.
- Add green chili, chopped tomatoes, tomato puree, capsicum, and water; cook until tomatoes turn mushy.
- Season with masala and cook off the moisture.
- Reduce heat to low and pour in whisked eggs; cook gently for 3-4 minutes without stirring much.
- Turn off the heat; add fresh cream, a touch of butter, and fresh chopped coriander; mix well.
- Toast pav bread with butter and optionally grate parmesan cheese on top before serving.

name: Cucumber Curd Sandwich
instructions:
prep_step:
- Grate the cucumber and squeeze out excess water if needed.
- In a bowl, mix grated cucumber with curd, salt, black pepper, chopped green chili, and coriander leaves.

quick_step:
- Grate cucumber and prepare curd mixture.
- Mix cucumber with curd and seasonings.
- Spread the mixture on bread slices.

name: Veg Mayo Sandwich
instructions:
prep_step:
- Chop capsicum, carrots, cucumber, and tomato into small pieces.
- Mix the chopped vegetables with black pepper powder, salt, and mayonnaise until well combined.

quick_step:
- Chop vegetables and mix with mayonnaise, salt, and pepper.
- Apply butter on both sides of bread slices.
- Spread the vegetable mixture on one bread slice.
- Place the other bread slice on top.
- Cut the sandwich and serve.

name: Paneer Corn Sandwich
instructions:
prep_step:
- Take paneer cubes and sweet corn in a bowl.
- Add pepper powder, salt, oregano, chilli flakes, schezwan sauce, red chilli sauce, tomato ketchup, and mayonnaise to the bowl.
- Mix all the ingredients well to prepare the stuffing.

quick_step:
- Prepare stuffing by mixing paneer, sweet corn, spices, sauces, and mayonnaise.
- Spread green chutney on bread slices.
- Add stuffing and cheese on bread, sprinkle spices, and cover with another slice.
- Butter the sandwich and toast on both sides until golden and crispy.
- Cut into slices and serve with your favorite dip.

cook_step:
- Apply green chutney on each bread slice.
- Evenly spread the prepared stuffing on the bread slices.
- Top the stuffing with cheese slices and sprinkle oregano and chilli flakes.
- Cover with another bread slice to form a sandwich.
- Apply butter on both sides of the sandwich.
- Toast the sandwiches on a pan or sandwich maker until golden brown on both sides.

name: Simple Stuffed Paratha Roll Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Mix wheat flour with salt and pepper.
- Add oil and water gradually to knead a soft dough.
- Chop onion and tomato finely if using.

quick_step:
- Prepare dough by mixing flour, salt, pepper, and oil.
- Knead dough until soft and rest for a few minutes.
- Roll dough into flat circles.
- Cook parathas on a hot pan with oil until golden and cooked through.
- Serve warm with curd and optional onion-tomato salad.

cook_step:
- Roll out the dough into flat circles.
- Cook each paratha on a hot tawa, applying oil on both sides until golden brown and slightly crispy.
- Serve hot with curd and optionally with chopped onion and tomato.

name: Paneer Kathi Roll Snack
instructions:
prep_step:
- Mix curd, mustard oil, Kashmiri red chilli powder, garam masala, kasuri methi powder, ginger garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt in a bowl.
- Add paneer cubes to the marinade and mix well to coat evenly.
- Prepare Lachha Paratha using wheat flour and roll it out.

quick_step:
- Marinate paneer with spices, curd, and mustard oil.
- Prepare and cook Lachha Paratha.
- Cook marinated paneer in a pan.
- Spread sauces and add cooked paneer with vegetables on paratha.
- Roll and wrap the paneer roll for serving.

cook_step:
- Apply oil to the pan and cook the marinated paneer until done.
- Spread red chilli sauce on the Lachha Paratha.
- Add cooked paneer, sliced tomato, and onion on top.
- Sprinkle chilli powder and black pepper powder for extra spice.
- Add green chilli sauce and tomato ketchup.
- Roll the paratha tightly with the fillings inside and wrap it in paper.

name: Chicken Tikka Masala Recipe
instructions:
prep_step:
- Cube chicken to 1 to 1one-half inch pieces. Add them to a mixing bowl. Make sure there is no excess moisture in your chicken. If you want you may pat dry with a few kitchen tissues.
- Add red chilli powder, garam masala, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric, salt, lemon juice, oil, ginger garlic paste, yogurt and kasuri methi. Skip the lemon juice if your yogurt is sour.
- Mix well. Cover with a cling wrap and refrigerate for minimum of 8 hours and up to 48 hours. If you are in a rush, you may cut down to 3 hours.
- Heat oil or ghee in a pot or pan. Add onions and sprinkle five g salt. Saute until deep golden.
- Add ginger garlic paste and green chilli. Saute until aromatic, for 40 to 60 seconds.
- Reduce the heat to low. Add red chilli powder, coriander powder, garam masala and cumin powder. Stir well quickly.
- Add the tomatoes and cook on a medium high heat until the onion tomato masala becomes really thick. (If using fresh tomatoes, it takes about 7 to 8 mins and tomato puree/passata takes only 2 minutes)
- Pour hot water and mix well. Bring to a rolling boil and cover. Simmer until thick, for about 12 to 14 mins.
- Optional – Cool down and blend to a smooth puree. Return it to the pot and heat up. This step cuts down the acidity from canned tomatoes.
- Grill in Oven : While the gravy simmers, thread the chicken to the metal skewers or soaked bamboo skewers and place them in a prepared tray. Bake them in a preheated oven at 460 F or 240 C for 9 to 10 mins. Turn them to the other side with a tong and grill then for another 9 to 10 mins. To char the chicken, broil for 2 to 3 mins or until slightly charred.
- Or In a Skillet: Pour fifteen ml oil to a skillet and heat it well. Place the chicken tikka one by one, spacing them apart. Cook on a medium high heat for 3 mins, turn them to the other side with a tong and cook for another 3 mins, until charred and   not essentially fully cooked. Remove to a plate and Cook in batches.
- Or In the Air fryer: Thread on skewers and place them in the basket or in the tray. Air fry for 6 mins, at 400 F or 200 C. Turn them with tongs and air fry for another 6 mins. If they dry out, you may baste with marinade and continue for another 2 mins, until slightly charred.
- After 12 to 14 mins of simmering the tikka masala sauce, add sugar and the cream (or cashew cream, check notes to make your own). Stir well and cook for a few minutes until thick, creamy and aromatic. (Check video for consistency)
- Add the grilled chicken tikka and crushed kasuri methi. (Make sure your gravy has reached a thick gravy consistency/serving consistency, before adding chicken). Stir and cook for 2 to 3 mins until chicken tikka is soft and tender. Taste test and add more salt, garam masala and sugar if needed.
- Turn off and garnish with cream and coriander leaves. Serve chicken tikka masala with Butter Naan, roti, paratha, Basmati rice or Jeera rice.
- You can start with chopped tomatoes if you intend to puree the sauce/gravy.
- Avoid using Canned tomatoes with citric acid added to it.
- Avoid using sour yogurt. If it is even slightly sour, avoid using lemon juice.
- To make the cashew cream, powder cashews finely in a grinder jar and pour seventy nine and 0.2 ml water to it. Grind to a smooth thick creamy paste. You will get half cup cashew cream. Later pour 3 tbsps water and swirl the jar and pour that as well to the gravy. If you do not have a powerful grinder, you may soak the cashews in seventy nine and 0.2 ml hot water for 15 mins, grind them with the same water to a smooth puree. I have tried and both work equally well.
- If cooking tikkas on the pan, they don’t need to be fully cooked but must be almost there. If you try to fully cook, they may dry out, turn hard and chewy.
- To make this authentic Indian, add 1 bay leaf, 3 to 4 cardamoms, cloves, 2 inch cinnamon to the hot oil before sautéing the onions. Also add bell peppers and onions to the marinade before grilling them. Use mustard oil for the tikkas.
- Make this ahead by splitting the recipe. Marinate chicken the previous night. Also make the gravy till the tikka sauce the previous day. The next day grill the tikkas and heat the gravy, add the cream and simmer. Later add the tikkas.
- To mimic the smoky flavor of the Tandoor, you may smoke your chicken tikka masala. For that, Place a small piece of foil or a tall steel cup on the finished chicken tikka masala. Hold 1 to 2 inch piece of natural wood charcoal with a tong and burn it on direct fire until red hot. Later place it on the foil kept over the curry or in the steel cup. Quickly pour one and one-quarter ml ghee on the hot coal. Immediately cover the pot and smoke for 4 to 5 mins. For stronger flavor, add another one and one-quarter ml ghee on the coal and repeat the smoking. If you overdo this, it will have very strong smoky flavors, so be cautious. You may check my Dal Makhani video to see how I actually do it.
- To make more servings , start with four hundred and eighty ml of water if using cashews, (or two hundred and forty ml water if using only heavy cream). As you cook, add half cup more at a time only if required (for 2x & 3x). Taste test the gravy after cooking, onions should be tender and soft but not crunchy or partially cooked. If they are undercooked, pour more hot water and simmer until well cooked.
- For 2x and 3x, double and triple the quantity of cashews and water for cashew cream. Cashews have a thickening property, if you reduce the quantity of water your curry won’t turn thick.

cook_step:
- Cube chicken to 1 to 1one-half inch pieces. Add them to a mixing bowl. Make sure there is no excess moisture in your chicken. If you want you may pat dry with a few kitchen tissues.
- Add red chilli powder, garam masala, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric, salt, lemon juice, oil, ginger garlic paste, yogurt and kasuri methi. Skip the lemon juice if your yogurt is sour.
- Mix well. Cover with a cling wrap and refrigerate for minimum of 8 hours and up to 48 hours. If you are in a rush, you may cut down to 3 hours.
- Heat oil or ghee in a pot or pan. Add onions and sprinkle five g salt. Saute until deep golden.

- Reduce the heat to low. Add red chilli powder, coriander powder, garam masala and cumin powder. Stir well quickly.

- Avoid using sour yogurt. If it is even slightly sour, avoid using lemon juice.

Hold 1 to 2 inch piece of natural wood charcoal with a tong and burn it on direct fire until red hot. Later place it on the foil kept over the curry or in the steel cup. Quickly pour one and one-quarter ml ghee on the hot coal. Immediately cover the pot and smoke for 4 to 5 mins. For stronger flavor, add another one and one-quarter ml ghee on the coal and repeat the smoking. If you overdo this, it will have very strong smoky flavors, so be cautious. You may check my Dal Makhani video to see how I actually do it.

As you cook, add half cup more at a time only if required (for 2x & 3x). Taste test the gravy after cooking, onions should be tender and soft but not crunchy or partially cooked. If they are undercooked, pour more hot water and simmer until well cooked.
- For 2x and 3x, double and triple the quantity of cashews and water for cashew cream. Cashews have a thickening property, if you reduce the quantity of water your curry won’t turn thick.

name: Ring Samosa Chaat
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil and mash the potatoes, then mix with spices to make potato masala.
- Thinly slice the onion and chop fresh coriander.
- Prepare samosa dough and roll it out.

quick_step:
- Shape samosa dough into rings and fry until crisp.
- Prepare spiced potato masala.
- Arrange fried rings and fill with potato masala.
- Top with onion slices and garnish with coriander.

cook_step:
- Use a ring mold to shape the samosa dough into rings and create holes with a fork.
- Heat oil to medium hot and fry the dough rings until golden and crisp.
- Remove fried rings and spread them on the sides of a serving plate.
- Fill the center with potato masala and place a small fried ring on top.
- Add sliced onions in the center and garnish with fresh coriander.

name: Papdi Chaat
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil and dice the potatoes.
- Boil the chickpeas until soft.
- Whisk the yogurt until smooth.
- Chop fresh coriander leaves.

quick_step:
- Boil and prepare potatoes and chickpeas.
- Whisk yogurt and prepare chutneys.
- Layer papdi with potatoes, chickpeas, yogurt, and chutneys.
- Sprinkle chaat masala, cumin powder, chili powder, sev, and coriander leaves.
- Serve immediately to enjoy the crispy texture.

cook_step:
- No cooking required; assemble the chaat by layering papdi, potatoes, chickpeas, yogurt, chutneys, and spices.

name: Masala Sweet Corn Cup
instructions:
prep_step:
- Boil or steam the sweet corn kernels until tender.
- Chop fresh coriander leaves finely.

quick_step:
- Boil sweet corn kernels until tender.
- Sauté corn in butter with spices.
- Add lemon juice and coriander before serving.

cook_step:
- Heat butter in a pan on medium flame.
- Add boiled sweet corn kernels to the pan and sauté for 2-3 minutes.
- Sprinkle chili powder, chaat masala, and salt over the corn and mix well.
- Turn off the flame and add lemon juice and chopped coriander leaves. Mix gently.

name: Chicken Korma Recipe
instructions:
prep_step:
- Bone-in chicken tastes best in this recipe as the juices from the bones seep to the korma and make the gravy delicious.
- Marinating the chicken is optional. It is just done to tenderize the meat. If you prefer to skip the step, add all of the marinade ingredients together to the pan along with chicken.
- A korma curry gets its creamy texture from yogurt and nut paste. Traditional korma recipe does not use any kind of starch to thicken the curry.
- The aroma comes from the fried onion paste, take care to fry the onions evenly.
- If you have a nut allergy just skip the nuts in the recipe and add more yogurt or use coconut milk.
- Marinade: To a mixing bowl, add the ingredients mentioned under the tittle Marinade – chicken, yogurt, ginger garlic, turmeric, salt, red chili powder and garam masala. Mix well to coat the chicken with the ingredients. Cover and keep aside.
- Make the korma paste: Heat a pan with ghee/oil and add 2 cardamoms and onions. Saute until they turn golden brown and begin to caramelize (not burnt). Add the nuts and cool down. Blend to a smooth paste with yogurt.
- Saute chicken: In the same pan, heat ghee/oil and add the optional whole spices – bay leaf, cinnamon stick, cloves and cardamom. When they begin to sizzle, add green chili and chicken. Saute on a medium heat for 5 to 6 mins.
- Make Chicken Korma: Add the onion puree, salt, coriander powder, garam masala and chili powder (optional, for deeper color). Stir in the hot water and rise the heat to bring to a boil. Cover and cook on a medium low heat until the chicken is cooked through & you see traces of oil over the korma.
- Troubleshooting: If the sauce is too thick to your liking, stir little hot water and simmer. If it is runny cook uncovered on a high heat, for a few minutes until thick. Taste test and adjust salt.
- Garnish with coriander leaves. Serve chicken korma with Jeera rice , plain Basmati Rice , Butter Naan , roti or paratha.
- You may omit the whole spices but they release a nice aroma when added to the hot oil. It is hard to find and remove them from the sauce later, if you are afraid of biting into them, simply omit.
- The amount of water to use varies & depends on the kind of chicken. Older birds and organic poultry require more water. So add water only in batches as you cook.
- If you do not have a powerful blender, you may blend the onions and nuts with half cup water called in the recipe.

name: Chicken 65 Recipe
instructions:
prep_step:
- Cut the chicken to approximately 1 by 1 inch pieces. Try to keep the sizes as uniform as possible, this helps in getting all the pieces fried evenly.
- To a large mixing bowl, add chicken, salt, turmeric, red chilli powder, garam masala, ginger garlic paste, lemon juice, yogurt and finely chopped curry leaves.
- Mix well and cover. Marinate for a minimum of 1 hour. You can refrigerate for upto to 36 hours.
- Prepare all the ingredients to temper before frying the chicken. Pat dry the curry leaves and deseeded green chilies. Keep them aside.
- To a small bowl add the crushed garlic paste, red chili powder, sugar & lemon/ vinegar/ yogurt (optional). If not using yogurt pour water. Mix together to get a thick paste. Keep this aside. one-half to fifteen g garlic paste, ten g Kashmiri red chili powder, two and one-half g sugar, five ml lemon juice or vinegar (optional, or sixty ml thick yogurt), thirty ml water (leave out if using yogurt to temper)
- On a medium flame, heat oi in a heavy bottom deep pan for frying. While the oil heats up, add cornstarch, rice flour and egg white to the marinated chicken.
- Mix well to coat the chicken well with flour and eggs or yogurt. The coating should be moist and not runny or too dry. If it is too dry, you may splash some water and mix well.
- Test if the oil is hot enough by dropping a pinch of batter in the hot oil. It must come up immediately without becoming brown. If it sinks and remains there, it means the oil is not hot enough yet.
- When the oil is hot enough, gently drop the chicken pieces into the oil. Do not crowd the pan.
- Do not disturb the chicken pieces for 2 minutes. Stir and let them cook on a medium heat until crisp and golden. Reduce the heat slightly and let them fry the last 1 minute until deep golden & really crisp.
- Remove them to a steel colander and continue to fry them in batches.
- Once you are done with the chicken, reduce the flame to lowest and place 2 sprigs of curry leaves on a skimmer or strainer ladle and gently lower to the hot oil. Fry the curry leaves until crisp. Remove to the colander.
- Place your slit and deseeded green chilies on the strainer ladle and lower it to the hot oil. Fry them until blistered. Turn off the heat. Toss all of these and serve this Chennai style Chicken 65 immediately or go ahead with the tempering below.
- To Bake in the oven, preheat the oven to 200 C or 390 F for at least 15 mins. Place the chicken pieces on a tray lined with parchment paper or foil. Bake for 35 to 40 mins, flipping after 20 mins. When the chicken is almost done, Place the curry leaves and slit green chilies. Broil for 2 mins. Adjust the baking time as every oven is different.
- Place the chicken on an air fryer parchment paper (perforated parchment paper). Air fry at 375 F or 180 C for 8 minutes, flip them and air fry for another 3 to 4 mins depending on how dry or crispy you want it. Place the sprig of curry leaves and slit green chilies and air fry for 2 more mins. Adjust the timings a bit as every air fryer is different.
- Pour thirty ml oil to wok. You can use fresh oil or use the same fried chicken oil. When the oil turns hot, add chopped garlic, 5 to 6 curry leaves and 2 slit green chilies. Stir fry until the curry leaves turn crisp, do not brown the garlic.
- Slide the curry leaves and the chilies to a side in the wok. Lower the heat completely and pour the chilli garlic paste, thirty ml water and salt. Mix well and let it cook on a medium heat until all of the water evaporates.
- Taste test the fried chicken and the sauce too. Adjust your sauce to your liking, by adding more salt or red chilli to your taste.
- Once it is done, you should have a thick oily chilli sauce in the wok. Add the fried chicken (set aside the previously deep fried curry leaves and green chilies for garnish).
- Turn off and Toss well to coat the chicken with the tempering. Garnish chicken 65 with crunchy curry leaves and green chilies. Squeeze some lemon juice and serve with fresh cut raw onions.
- Please note you have to 2x & 3x the substitutes mentioned in the brackets if you are trying to make 2x & 3x.
- If using yogurt to temper, begin to cook at a low heat after adding the chilli garlic paste. We don’t want the yogurt to split.
- To make it kids’ friendly simply skip the tempering for the kids portion. You can also reduce the red chilli powder from the marinade.
- You may use bone-in chicken or boneless chicken thighs or breasts. If using bone-in chicken or breasts, it is essential to rest the marinated chicken for a minimum of 4 to 6 hours else they will dry out and turn chewy.
- Egg white can be replaced with curd.
- The proportion of yogurt, egg and flour is very important. If you alter this, the coating from the chicken may fall off.
- If using a strong garam masala, use it in combination with other spices like cumin and coriander. The coating may taste bitter if you add a lot of garam masala or red chilli powder.
- Sugar in the tempering cuts down the pungent flavor from garlic. It also helps to keep the chicken crisp after tempering. Vinegar or lemon juice also cuts down the pungent flavor from garlic.
- Chili Garlic paste:  My family loves this with fifteen g garlic paste in the chilli garlic paste, you may cut down if you don’t prefer pungent taste or flavor.

cook_step:
- Cut the chicken to approximately 1 by 1 inch pieces. Try to keep the sizes as uniform as possible, this helps in getting all the pieces fried evenly.
- To a large mixing bowl, add chicken, salt, turmeric, red chilli powder, garam masala, ginger garlic paste, lemon juice, yogurt and finely chopped curry leaves.
- Mix well and cover. Marinate for a minimum of 1 hour. You can refrigerate for upto to 36 hours.
- Prepare all the ingredients to temper before frying the chicken. Pat dry the curry leaves and deseeded green chilies. Keep them aside.
- To a small bowl add the crushed garlic paste, red chili powder, sugar & lemon/ vinegar/ yogurt (optional). If not using yogurt pour water. Mix together to get a thick paste. Keep this aside. one-half to fifteen g garlic paste, ten g Kashmiri red chili powder, two and one-half g sugar, five ml lemon juice or vinegar (optional, or sixty ml thick yogurt), thirty ml water (leave out if using yogurt to temper)
- On a medium flame, heat oi in a heavy bottom deep pan for frying. While the oil heats up, add cornstarch, rice flour and egg white to the marinated chicken.

- Remove them to a steel colander and continue to fry them in batches.

- You may use bone-in chicken or boneless chicken thighs or breasts. If using bone-in chicken or breasts, it is essential to rest the marinated chicken for a minimum of 4 to 6 hours else they will dry out and turn chewy.
- Egg white can be replaced with curd.
- The proportion of yogurt, egg and flour is very important. If you alter this, the coating from the chicken may fall off.
- If using a strong garam masala, use it in combination with other spices like cumin and coriander. The coating may taste bitter if you add a lot of garam masala or red chilli powder.
- Sugar in the tempering cuts down the pungent flavor from garlic. It also helps to keep the chicken crisp after tempering. Vinegar or lemon juice also cuts down the pungent flavor from garlic.
- Chili Garlic paste:  My family loves this with fifteen g garlic paste in the chilli garlic paste, you may cut down if you don’t prefer pungent taste or flavor.

name: Chicken Fry Recipe (Andhra Kodi Vepudu)
instructions:
prep_step:
- Optional – To make garam masala, dry roast all the whole spices on a medium heat until aromatic and crunchy. Make a fine powder.
- Add chicken to a large pot along with thirty ml water. Add crushed onions, ginger garlic paste, garam masala, chili powder, salt, turmeric, ghee and lemon juice.
- On a medium flame, cook the chicken till it is soft cooked and tender. Little water can be added while cooking if the chicken turns dry. Once done, turn off the heat. Excess moisture in the pot at this stage is alright.
- If you want you may cool this and refrigerate immediately. Fry the chicken only when required, for up to 2 days.
- Heat oil or ghee in a pan, add curry leaves and green chilies.
- Fry till the leaves turn crisp and aromatic.
- Add the cooked chicken along with the stock/ masala. Add the cashew powder and pepper powder.
- Fry on a medium high flame till all the excess moisture is evaporated.
- Keep stirring well and fry for 3 to 4 mins or till you get a nice aroma of cashews. The masala should coat the chicken well. If you want add little ghee at this stage.
- Garnish chicken fry with fresh chopped coriander leaves. Sprinkle some lemon juice and serve hot with rice, rasam or any vegetable curry.

cook_step:
- Optional – To make garam masala, dry roast all the whole spices on a medium heat until aromatic and crunchy. Make a fine powder.
- Add chicken to a large pot along with thirty ml water. Add crushed onions, ginger garlic paste, garam masala, chili powder, salt, turmeric, ghee and lemon juice.
- On a medium flame, cook the chicken till it is soft cooked and tender. Little water can be added while cooking if the chicken turns dry. Once done, turn off the heat. Excess moisture in the pot at this stage is alright.
- If you want you may cool this and refrigerate immediately. Fry the chicken only when required, for up to 2 days.
- Heat oil or ghee in a pan, add curry leaves and green chilies.
- Fry till the leaves turn crisp and aromatic.
- Add the cooked chicken along with the stock/ masala. Add the cashew powder and pepper powder.
- Fry on a medium high flame till all the excess moisture is evaporated.
- Keep stirring well and fry for 3 to 4 mins or till you get a nice aroma of cashews. The masala should coat the chicken well. If you want add little ghee at this stage.
- Garnish chicken fry with fresh chopped coriander leaves. Sprinkle some lemon juice and serve hot with rice, rasam or any vegetable curry.

name: Chicken Curry Recipe
instructions:
prep_step:
- Fine chop the onions so they cook down to a jammy texture in the curry. This also helps to cook the onions faster. You may use a chopper or food processor for that.
- You can use chopped tomatoes or pureed tomatoes. I prefer to peel and deseed the tomatoes if using them in chopped form. If you want to use canned tomatoes or passata, you will need higher amount of ground spices.
- The specialty of this chicken curry is to slow cook on a low heat. Do not hurry up to finish the dish. A slow cooked dish is worth the effort as it really stands out in taste & flavor. A chicken curry prepared on a high heat yields a hotchpotch curry and not the one that you will really love & enjoy.
- On a medium flame, heat oil in a deep pan.  Add the whole spices – bay leaf, cinnamon, cloves & green cardamoms.
- Stir in the chopped onions and chilies. Saute until deep golden in color, for 7 to 8 mins.
- Add ginger garlic paste and saute till you get a nice aroma, for about a minute.
- Then add tomatoes, turmeric and salt. Mix well and cook until the tomatoes turn soft & mushy.
- Turn down the heat to low, Stir in the yogurt (or cashew paste), red chili powder, garam masala & coriander powder.
- Cook on low heat, until the mixture smells good and aromatic.
- Add chicken and coriander leaves. Fry on a medium heat till the chicken turns white or pale in color. This takes around 3 mins.
- Cover and cook on a low heat for 3 to 4 minutes. This step is very important as the chicken absorbs all the flavors of the spices.
- Meanwhile in a separate pot, heat up two hundred and forty ml water. Using cold water most times toughens the chicken so it is good to use hot water.
- Pour hot water just enough (about one hundred and twenty g) to make a thick gravy. As you cook, chicken lets out plenty of moisture, depending on that add more water. Check the pictures in the post for consistency.
- Cover and cook on a medium flame till the chicken is soft cooked and the curry/gravy turns thick. When the chicken is cooked completely it will fall off the bone easily.
- Taste the curry & add more salt if needed. You can also add another two and one-half g garam masala at this stage if you feel it is less in flavors.
- Lastly garnish with coriander leaves, cover and off the heat. Serve chicken curry with butter naan or jeera rice .
- You leave out the whole spices if you do not have. But they add a more intense flavor to the curry.
- To prevent yogurt from splitting, add it to a bowl and whisk it well with a fork. Add 2 tbsps of onion tomato masala (made in the recipe) and mix it well with yogurt. Then lower the flame completely and pour the yogurt to the pan.
- To substitute yogurt, use 1.5 tbsps cashew butter or soak 12 cashew nuts or almonds or forty five g of white poppy seeds in half cup water for 30 minutes. Later blend it with 4 to ninety ml water in a small grinder to make super smooth milk.
- If you don’t like chunky curry with onions and tomatoes then blend the onion tomato masala with half cup water in a blender.
- Adding cold water to chicken sometimes makes it hard or tough. So use hot water.
- This chicken curry can be cooked in coconut milk instead of water. Do not pour cold coconut milk. Heat up and add.
- Please choose a good garam masala for the recipe especially if using store bought. Some brands sell really pungent garam masala. Use it with caution.
- You can also use 3 to 4 tbsps of cream or thick coconut milk towards the end if you prefer. Just add it towards the end and turn off.

cook_step:
- Fine chop the onions so they cook down to a jammy texture in the curry. This also helps to cook the onions faster. You may use a chopper or food processor for that.
- You can use chopped tomatoes or pureed tomatoes. I prefer to peel and deseed the tomatoes if using them in chopped form. If you want to use canned tomatoes or passata, you will need higher amount of ground spices.
- The specialty of this chicken curry is to slow cook on a low heat. Do not hurry up to finish the dish. A slow cooked dish is worth the effort as it really stands out in taste & flavor. A chicken curry prepared on a high heat yields a hotchpotch curry and not the one that you will really love & enjoy.

- Stir in the chopped onions and chilies. Saute until deep golden in color, for 7 to 8 mins.

name: Pepper Chicken Recipe
instructions:
prep_step:
- Marinate chicken with ingredients under marination. Keep it aside until needed.
- Pour oil to a hot pan. Add cumin, cinnamon, cloves and cardamom. Allow them to sizzle.
- Next add curry leaves and ginger garlic paste. Fry till the raw smell of ginger garlic goes off.
- Add onions and fry till they turn golden.
- Then add tomatoes and salt. Fry till the tomatoes turn mushy and soft.
- Add red chili powder, garam masala and coarsely crushed pepper corn.
- Fry everything well till the mixture looses all the moisture.
- Add chicken and fry for about 3 to 4 minutes.
- Cover and cook on a low flame till the chicken turns tender.
- If the chicken doesn't let out enough moisture to cook, then add little water.
- Cover and cook until soft. If you want to have gravy,
- You can take it off while there is moisture. You can also pour 3 to sixty ml coconut milk.
- If you prefer a dry version, cook without lid and evaporate the moisture in the chicken. fry till all the moisture dries up.
- Serve pepper chicken hot with rice and Rasam . Squeeze in some lemon juice before serving.

cook_step:
- Marinate chicken with ingredients under marination. Keep it aside until needed.

- Add onions and fry till they turn golden.
- Then add tomatoes and salt. Fry till the tomatoes turn mushy and soft.
- Add red chili powder, garam masala and coarsely crushed pepper corn.
- Fry everything well till the mixture looses all the moisture.
- Add chicken and fry for about 3 to 4 minutes.
- Cover and cook on a low flame till the chicken turns tender.
- If the chicken doesn't let out enough moisture to cook, then add little water.
- Cover and cook until soft. If you want to have gravy,
- You can take it off while there is moisture. You can also pour 3 to sixty ml coconut milk.
- If you prefer a dry version, cook without lid and evaporate the moisture in the chicken. fry till all the moisture dries up.
- Serve pepper chicken hot with rice and Rasam . Squeeze in some lemon juice before serving.

name: Masala Chai Recipe (Authentic Indian Spiced Milk Tea)
instructions:
prep_step:
- Milk: The amount of milk added varies from person to person. So you can add milk as per your preference.
- Tea type: The type of tea also makes a difference to the overall flavor. I always use Assam tea as it is stronger than Darjeeling tea. But I do know some folks who prefer a mix of Assam + Darjeeling tea or only Darjeeling tea. What I have used here is organic Assam tea which is not the same as tea leaves, but in granules. You may use either one.
- Spices: You may adjust the quantity of spices as required. I would suggest reducing the quantity of spice in the summertime as spices increase body heat and sweating. Increasing the quantity of spice may help to keep the body warm during winter or also when you have cold.
- Making tea: The classic way of making tea is to steep the tea leaves in hot water. The Indian method is boiling the tea leaves for some minutes. I usually add milk later. Though in some families, water, milk and tea leaves are boiled together.
- Strong tea: This recipe is a strong tea due to the taste and aroma of Assam tea along with the flavor of the spices. Adjust the amount of ginger to suit your taste.
- Adrak Chai (Ginger Tea) – Spiced Indian tea brewed with fresh ginger, milk, and black tea for a warm, soothing flavor; especially comforting in cold weather.
- Cutting Chai – Mumbai’s iconic half-glass chai, strong and brisk, often served at roadside stalls in small glasses with a punchy flavor.
- Irani Chai – A creamy, slow-brewed tea made with a strong black tea decoction and thickened, sweetened milk. Popular in the Irani cafés of Hyderabad, Mumbai, and Pune.
- Pudina Chai (Mint Tea) – Refreshing Indian-style tea brewed with fresh mint leaves, offering a cooling contrast to the warmth of the tea.
- Herbal Chai – Made with, ginger, lemongrass and mint, this soothing and comforting chai is perfect for any time of the day.
- Kahwa Tea – A delicate Kashmiri green tea infused with saffron, cardamom, cinnamon, and almonds; fragrant and gently spiced.
- Sulaimani Tea – A clear, spiced black tea from Kerala and Hyderabad, lightly sweetened and often finished with a dash of lemon juice. Perfect after meals.
- Green Tea – Light and antioxidant-rich, typically made without milk or sugar. Enjoyed plain or with lemon or honey.
- Turmeric Tea – A healing herbal infusion made with turmeric, black pepper, and sometimes ginger, known for its anti-inflammatory and immunity-boosting properties
- Take cinnamon, green cardamoms, cloves and peeled ginger in a mortar-pestle.
- In a sauce pan or a small pan with a handle, heat water.
- Let the water come to a boil and then add the crushed spices.
- Boil the spices along with the water for 2 to 3 minutes.
- Add sugar as per taste. I usually add twenty g of raw sugar. You can add more or less.
- Now add ten g of assam tea powder. Boil for a minute. This boiling time depends on how strong you want your tea. If you prefer a strong intense tea, then boil for a few more minutes.
- Add milk. After adding milk boil for 2 to 3 minutes.
- If using chilled milk, then boil with tea for 2 to 3 minutes. If using hot milk, then add the milk and switch off the heat.
- Pour the tea through a tea strainer directly in the cup.
- Serve Masala Chai hot with some Indian snacks or cookies or biscuits.

name: Irani Chai Recipe (Cafe Style Irani Tea)
instructions:
prep_step:
- Tea Decoction : Strong black tea is simmered for a long time with spices like cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon in water. This creates a bold, intense tea concentrate.
- Milk Base : Separately, whole milk is simmered slowly with sugar until it becomes slightly thick and creamy.
- Use full-fat milk: To achieve the signature richness Irani Chai is known for, full-fat milk is non-negotiable. Toned or skim milk just won’t give you the velvety body this chai demands. The creamier, the better.
- Go for strong Assam CTC tea: For that bold, malty depth and the beautiful reddish-brown hue, choose robust Assam CTC (Crush-Tear-Curl) tea. It holds up well to the long simmer and cuts through the creaminess. Skip light-bodied teas like Darjeeling or any flavored blends as they lack the punch needed here.
- Slow-reduce the milk: Let the milk gently simmer on low heat until it reduces by about 20 to 25%. This slow evaporation intensifies the creaminess and gives the tea its signature creamy texture.
- Brew the decoction separately: Steep the tea leaves in water with a touch of cardamom, and optionally, clove or cinnamon for a whisper of warmth. Avoid boiling the tea leaves directly in milk as it muddies the flavor and compromises clarity.
- Adjust sweetness: The sweetness of Irani Tea can vary from mildly sweet to decadently sugary, depending on your preference. Traditionally, a generous amount of sugar is added to the milk while it simmers, which balances the strong decoction beautifully.
- Alternative sweeteners: Jaggery or unrefined cane sugar can offer a more earthy sweetness, though they may slightly alter the color.
- Strain for a smooth sip: Straining both the decoction and the milk (especially if it’s developed a layer of malai) ensures a clean, silky finish.
- Combine just before serving: Pour the tea decoction into the reduced milk, not the other way around. This allows you to control the balance of strength and creaminess with each cup.
- Optional aromatics: For a luxurious touch, stir in two to three drops of rose water or kewra essence just before serving – an homage to the old Irani cafés where aroma was as important as taste.
- Vegan Options: For a vegan version, try almond or cashew milk, but simmer gently as they thicken differently than dairy.
- In a saucepan, heat full-fat milk or whole milk.
- Bring it to a boil and simmer on low to medium-low heat, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
- Let the milk reduce by about one-quarter over low to medium-low heat. This process takes around 15 to 20 minutes in total and makes the milk richer and slightly thicker, enhancing the creaminess of the chai.
- You'll know the milk is reduced when the volume is down to 1.one thousand two hundred g and the milk will look slightly creamier and richer in color.
- Once the milk has reduced and thickened, add sugar to it and stir to dissolve.
- Optional: Add a few drops of rose water or kewra water at the end for a floral aroma.
- Take the spices – cardamom, cloves and cinnamon in a mortar. Crush these lightly with a pestle.
- Meanwhile when the milk is simmering, in another saucepan, take water and the crushed spices.
- Bring this water added with the spices to a boil.
- Add black tea and simmer on low heat for about 3 to 5 minutes or until the water has a nice amber color. Opt to strain and keep the tea decoction hot in a flask if you prefer.
- Once the tea decoction is ready, turn off the heat of the stovetop where the milk is simmering. Lift the saucepan and pour about one-third to one hundred and twenty g thick hot milk into a cup.
- Take the saucepan with the hot tea decoction. Using a strainer, strain one-quarter to seventy nine and 0.2 g hot tea decoction in the cup with the thick milk. Adjust to taste depending on how strong or milky you want your Irani Chai.
- Stir gently and serve Irani Chai hot. Prepare Irani Tea this way in for more servings.
- Irani Chai is best served hot, paired with Osmania biscuits, bun maska, or khari biscuits.
- It also goes well with simple bakery-style cakes or rusk for a classic chai-time experience.

quick_step:

- Milk Base : Separately, whole milk is simmered slowly with sugar until it becomes slightly thick and creamy.
- Use full-fat milk: To achieve the signature richness Irani Chai is known for, full-fat milk is non-negotiable. Toned or skim milk just won’t give you the velvety body this chai demands. The creamier, the better.

name: Turmeric Milk | Golden Milk (Haldi Doodh)
instructions:
prep_step:
- If you can source fresh turmeric roots, use them in place of turmeric powder. Rinse them properly, grate them in the milk and let it cook for some minutes. For about two hundred and forty ml of milk, you can add up-to one-half to five g of grated fresh turmeric root. Add the amount as needed depending on your health conditions and taste preferences.
- Readymade turmeric powder is usually colored with a toxic chemical dye ‘metanil yellow.’ So, make sure to buy organic turmeric powder and always check the list of ingredients on the pack.
- Too much usage or consumption of turmeric may lead to side effects like diarrhoea, stomach upsets and nausea. So, use wisely and according to your body type and health needs.
- Choosing to consume Turmeric Milk every day should be based on your body constitution and health. The drink may or may not suit you. So, I recommend you to consult a certified dietician before you plan to drink it regularly.
- Heat milk in a saucepan on a low to medium flame.
- Simmer the milk for 2 to 3 minutes or until it boils. Once the milk starts boiling, turn off the heat.
- Pour the hot milk in a glass or mug.
- Add turmeric powder and black pepper powder.
- Stir and mix very well.
- Serve Turmeric Milk hot or warm.
